timeline.message: call spliterator directly, use page size 1000
output elements more eagerly in ListHL72MessageFn
eagerly emit data from early pages

Optimization of Listing and Stablization of ITs

* allow HL7v2 Message listing to emit early panes rather than waiting on pagination of all list results
* add EBO on HL7v2 Message listing reaching a certain expected length in ITs to account for async indexing BEAM-9779

timeline.bodyText: Is there any specific reason that the input is HttpBody instead of String? It feels weird to me because we only use the data field in the API client.
timeline.author: lastomato

replies.bodyText:
@lastomato
My original goal was just to mimic the client library as closely as possible to be familiar to users that are used to that interface and to smooth migration to use the client library (rather than using apache http clinet / requests as a workaround).
For example, if the signature was PTransform<PCollection, Write.Result> it might be confusing to a user if they need to base 64 encode the strings themselves or not.
I was also unsure if there would be some use cases where users would want to set certain other things like extensions or content type in the HttpBody. Though it's worth noting that in the current implementation we are hard coding content type and don't handle extensions.
If you feel strongly that the API should accept Strings I'm open to refactoring for that.
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText: discussed offline, will refactor to pass around as strings.
replies.author: jaketf

fix FHIR resource reading to use object mapper

timeline.author: jaketf

timeline.bodyText: is import method idempotent?
timeline.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
@pabloem FYI
Yes. it is idempotent.

The import operation is idempotent unless the input data contains multiple valid resources with the same ID but different contents. In that case, after the import completes, the store contains exactly one resource with each ID, but the duplicate entries could contain any version of the contents. For example, importing a million resources with the same ID writes only one resource to the store.

-FHIR Import Public Docs
replies.author: jaketf

timeline.bodyText: what happens if this gets rescheduled.
timeline.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
The steps of ImportFn are:

move files for this batch import call to a temp prefix (in order to capture with a single wildcard for the import API call) with a UUID
Make and FHIR Import call
Poll/block until this operation completes.
Clean up temp files

The FHIR import operation should be idempotent (see comment below).
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
Let's consider what happens if the process get killed / rescheduled between each of these setps



when?
GCS
FHIR Store
Notes




(1) -> (1) between non-atomic object moves on GCS
some objects moved to a tmp-UUID prefix.
No FHIR Import Job Attempted
when rescheduled, will try to import the subset of objects that were NOT moved. This is a very confusing state.


(1) -> (2)
objects moved to a tmp-UUID prefix.
No FHIR Import Job Attempted
when rescheduled we'll fail because  the original URIs don't exist.


(2) -> (3)
objects moved to a tmp-UUID prefix
an in-flight FHIR Import job that beam has lost track of. We could safely re-do this import job without consequence as it is idempotent.
However, a rescheduled attempt will fail as the original object URIs now will not exist because they've been "claimed" by being moved to the temp dir.


(3) -> (3) aka killed between polling calls:
In some cases where InterruptedException is thrown we will move the objects in questions to the dead letter path.
in-flight FHIR Import job may or may not succeed.
Potential for low consequence false negative: If user re-runs import from DLQ should be fine due to idempontency. But this could be wasteful if the original job in-fact succeeds


(3) -> (4):
tmp-UUID dir will not be cleaned up properly
FHIR Import Job succeeded
This is not a critical failure but inconvenient and will incur storage costs.
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
All critical failure scenarios can be addressed if we copy originally written files instead of renaming/moving them and update clean up logic to handle this.
There still may be issues of phantom temp dirs if the task is killed / rescheduled.
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
In 5540277 Refactored FhirIO.Import to:

copy (instead of rename) files to temp dirs.
delete everything from gcsTempDir once window has closed.

This addresses all issues in above table except being killed between polling calls.
To mitigate this we could split into a ImportFn that is responsible only for starting Import jobs and  outputs KV of Operation IDs and temp dirs and BlockTilDoneFn which handles blocking and clean up.
@pabloem thoughts on a cleaner way to do this?
replies.author: jaketf

timeline.message:
Clean up based on offline review feedback

* Add SDK version to user agent
* Improve naming of FetchString
* Add value provider support
Merge branch 'FhirIO' of github.com:jaketf/beam into FhirIO

Refactors Import to Copy and Clean Up

* Uses copy instead of rename in FhirIO.ImportFn to be more resilient to rescheduling
* adds .of() static methods for all coders
* make FhirIO.Import extend FhirIO.Write and return both body and file failures
improving coder interface and safety of FhirIO.Import

timeline.bodyText: Aren't these meant to be HealthcareIOMessage types?
timeline.author: pabloem

replies.bodyText:
Sorry for the confusion.
We used to pass resources around as HttpBody but we only ever use the String data field so we refactored to just pass around as strings.
This eliminated the need for a HttpBodyCoder which had proven to be problematic.
If you call readResult.getFailedReads() you will get PCollection which is effectively a DLQ to handle if you were trying to read a resource ID that doesn't exist (or some similar error).

timeline.bodyText: this function makes RPCs to an external service one-by-one. This will be slow. It may be worth buffering these requests, and applying them with a thread pool. You can add this optimization later on, though.
timeline.author: pabloem

replies.bodyText:
The Fhir.read api doesn't support requesting several resources in a single call.
We could look into Fhir.search to request all resources with IDs in a list.

replies.bodyText: You could perform multiple Fhir.read requests from separate threads? This may be fine for now, though, and if you find that the extra optimization will help, then add it later on?

timeline.bodyText: This is executing a single RPC per element, right? This will likely be slow, and lead to underutilization of worker resources. As a follow up, messages could be buffered, and RPCs issued via a thread pool
timeline.author: pabloem

replies.bodyText:
IMO Batching should be handled upstream from the connector based on what type of bundles the user is trying to commit to fire.
executeBundle is a single call per (beam) element (but each (beam) element in this case is already a FHIR Bundle) but in a transaction type bundle it's very crucial what elements are batched together (as they are committed as a single transaction on the back-end). The user must control this to get the desired behavior.
with batch type bundle the operations are executed individually on the back end (but provided by the client as a single call).
We could provide a convenience PTransform for buffering batches into a bundle.
context of what we support in Google HCAPI:
https://cloud.google.com/healthcare/docs/reference/rest/v1beta1/projects.locations.datasets.fhirStores.fhir/executeBundle
broader context of what the FHIR spec has for bundle type:
https://www.hl7.org/fhir/valueset-bundle-type.html
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText:
To be a bit clearer:

FHIR bundle is 1:1 with beam element here (but may contain many operations).
The FHIR bundle a field that dictates if it is transaction or batch type but they use the same endpoint / method.
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText: Makes sense. Sounds good to me!
replies.author: pabloem

revised_code.chunk:

timeline.bodyText: Howcome you receive a class but ignore it?
timeline.author: pabloem

replies.bodyText:
My understanding was this is necessary in order to use @Default.Coder(HL7v2MessageCoder) decorator on the HL7v2Message class.
However, I forgot to add that decorator so no wonder this looks confusing, good catch!
https://beam.apache.org/documentation/programming-guide/#default-coders-and-the-coderregistry

timeline.bodyText:
This is providing a static key, not a key-generating function, right?

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                              WithKeys.of(ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, numShards)))
          
          
            
                              WithKeys.of(elm -> ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, numShards)))
          
      
    
    
  

(I think)
timeline.author: pabloem

revised_code.chunk:
diff --git a/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/healthcare/FhirIO.java b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/healthcare/FhirIO.java
index 660f6d2d6b..dab165b3c1 100644
--- a/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/healthcare/FhirIO.java
+++ b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/healthcare/FhirIO.java

@@ -817,7 +817,7 @@ public class FhirIO {
               .get(Write.TEMP_FILES)
               .apply(
                   "Shard files", // to paralelize group into batches
-                  WithKeys.of(ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, numShards)))
+                  WithKeys.of(elm -> ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, numShards)))
               .apply("File Batches", GroupIntoBatches.ofSize(DEFAULT_FILES_PER_BATCH))
               .apply(
                   ParDo.of(new ImportFn(fhirStore, tempPath, deadLetterGcsPath, contentStructure)))

timeline.bodyText:
@lastomato @yeweidaniel @ygupta89 @pabloem
Please review the logic here and LMK if you feel this is spamming the import API.
As written this will create a separate new line delimited JSON file per bundle (group of elements in a PCollection of arbitrary size decided by runner) and import it w/ a separate call to import API.
This was the "easiest" way to implement but may not be the most appropriate usage of the import API.
PTAL and LMK if you'd like this to refactored into something that:

asserts bounded PCollection
waits til all temp files are written
blocks on import by polling the operation til complete.

It's not immediately obvious to me how to achieve 1 & 2 in the beam framework but I can do some research.
timeline.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText: I am a little worried about the fact that the bundle size is unknown. In extreme (though unlikely) cases, we could be making one import API call per resource.
replies.author: lastomato

replies.bodyText:
Research:

Based on this SO post
We might be able to GroupByKey single dummy key to encourage runner to do less bundle splitting, though I'm not sure that will really do the trick.
From Beam docs:


Specifically, it makes it impossible to batch any operations, such as writing elements to a sink or checkpointing progress during processing.
The division of the collection into bundles is arbitrary and selected by the runner. This allows the runner to choose an appropriate middle-ground between persisting results after every element, and having to retry everything if there is a failure. For example, a streaming runner may prefer to process and commit small bundles, and a batch runner may prefer to process larger bundles.
(source)

It seems to me that our predominant use case for Import is a batch pipeline and this sentence implies that bundles are larger in batch (not sure if we can find internal details on Dataflow Runner).

BigQueryIO has a batch loads pattern which seems similar to what we are aiming to achieve here. This seems quite complex and I'm wondering if there are simpler approaches elsewhere in the beam code base.

Do we have any guidance on how many parallel import operations would be acceptable? Perhaps we can run some benchmarks with 500, 1000, 10000 resources with this approach / adding group by single key and see if it's acceptable.
replies.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText: @pabloem is there a good way to signal to the runner to prefer large bundles for this DoFn? Are there any other common patterns for batching files for bulk import operations that are less complicated than the BQ File Loads (which seem to have a lot of complexity to handle dynamic destinations)?
replies.author: jaketf

timeline.bodyText:
@lastomato @yeweidaniel @ygupta89
This is super awkward but the executeBundle method of client lib seems broken always giving errors about unparsable resource based on my testing (CDAP plugins also written similar to this).
Any ETA on fix for that?
Does this workaround seem acceptable til then?
timeline.author: jaketf

replies.bodyText: There is no ETA for a fix, and it is out of our control. It is acceptable to me :)
replies.author: lastomato

timeline.message: DRY up GCS clean up in util
fix merge issue w/ duplicate google_oauth_clients_version
parameterize write ITs add scaffolidng for Read IT
add TODO to add support for batch API in the future once available
add reshuffle to increase downstream paralelism
add GroupIntoBatches logic to FhirIO.Import to write more resources to files
add GroupIntoBatches test for uneven batches

Refactor FhirIO.Import

This commit is the first in a series of explorations of best method
for batching files to a single GCS prefix for fhirStores.import call.

FhirIO.Import now follow the algorithm of:
- Write Bundles of input PCollection<HttpBody> to GCS
- GroupByKey (random key to parallelize GroupIntoBatches)
- GroupIntoBatches (of 10,000 files)
- move each batch of files to uniquely named GCS path
- make import calls for each of these GCS paths
fix auto value issue causing canot find symbol

Patches for HL7v2IO

* Use TestPipeline in ITs
* Drop schematized data before calling message ingest (should be output only) to help pipelines that read/write from/to two HL7v2 stores
* Make HL7v2MessageCoder constructor public
add sleep to avoid flakiness due to asyncronous HL7v2 indexing
